summary: viruliferous and non-viruliferous WBPH is a great threat to rice production in eastasia. viruliferous and non-viruliferous WBPH have a very similar gene ontological distribution to other closely related rice planthoppers. the most prevalent rice viruses are plant-infecting reoviruses in the genera Phytoreovirus, Fijivirus and Oryzavirus of the family Reoviridae. the most prevalent rice viruses are plant-infecting reoviruses in the genera Phytoreovirus. phylogenetic analyses show that SRBSDV has a high sequence similarity with RBSDV. segments S1 and S10 have the highest relatedness. molecular functions of the translated proteins have not been documented. resources available for WBPH are still scarce and searches in GenBank identified only about 156 WBPH ESTs. this limited amount of data provides little information for transcriptional, proteomic, and gene functional analysis of WBPH. next-generation high-throughput DNA sequencing technique has provided unprecedented opportunities for gene discovery of WBPH. sequence data from the two libraries were combined, and 81388 unigenes were finally obtained with a mean length of 555 bp. the length distribution of total unigenes had similar patterns between viruliferous and non-viruliferous samples. however, some unigenes were obtained only from viruliferous or non-viruliferous samples. a total of 28909 (5.52% of all distinct sequences) unigenes provided a BLAST result. the species distributions of the best match result for each sequence were shown in Figure 2 and Table S2. the sequences of WBPH shared the highest similarity with the red flour beetle. approximately 18045 (58.23%) of the unigenes could be annotated in GO based on sequence homology. GO analysis also showed a similar distribution of gene functions for non-viruliferous and viruliferous WBPH. 7.26% of protein-coding sequences possessed such repeats. trinucleotide repeats are the most abundant microsatellites in coding ESTs. previous work revealed that (AAC) n is the most frequent motif in L. striatellus [16] Totally, 58% of the differentially expressed genes were up-regulated in the viruliferous WBPH. the detected fold changes (log2 ratio) of gene expression ranged from 15 to +16. more than 80% of the genes were up- or down-regulated between 1.0 to 5.0 fold. nine of the selected unigenes were inconsistent between DGE and qRT-PCR. this difference might be caused by a lower sensitivity of qRT-PCR than DGE. qRT-PCR analysis confirmed the direction of change detected by DGE analysis, indicating that our results are reliable. SRBSDV-infected and un-infected rice seedlings were collected from fields and then moved to a beaker after discarding the old leaves. after two days of feeding, the rice seedlings were gently turned upside-down, and the juvenile planthoppers were swept onto healthy rice seedlings. cDNA library preparation and Illumina sequencing for transcriptome analysis RNA was purified from 20 mg of pooled total RNA using Oligo (dT) magnetic beads. the cleaved poly-(A) RNA was transcribed using Oligo (dT) (Takara, Japan), and then second-strand cDNA synthesis was performed.
